Comment: This is the French Defence. I used to play it a lot, so I know what is coming.

There are other moves here that I could play, such as Bg5, c3, Be3, Bc4 etc. The one that I selected takes the e4-square and potentially targets h7.
There are other moves here that I could play, such as Bg5, c3, Be3, Bc4 etc. The one that I selected takes the e4-square and potentially targets h7.
This is logical. Black challenges the central control by attacking d4.
I could take on c5, but instead, I move the king to a safer place. There is a little tactical trick that makes this possible, although d4 is threatened.
Black takes it.
And I take back! 9...Qxd4 would be followed by 10. Bb5+ winning the queen.
So Black develops a piece with tempo.
Keeping it simple.
Now I cannot pin the f6-knight.
I still move the bishop to g5, because other active squares are covered by Black pieces. I also have the option to break Black's kingside pawn structure.
Breaking the pawn structure here is probably not worth losing the bishop pair.
Breaking the pawn structure here is probably not worth losing the bishop pair.
Preparing to bring the bishop to b7.
This is a good square for the knight.
The rook takes the open file.

I do not like this move. Bringing a rook to oppose mine on the d-file would be better, I think.
Driving the knight away.
